Book																	99.99																				Add to Cart																																																				Executive Summary						Anxiety can cause you problems at work. Perhaps it leads you to misjudge what other people think of you, react defensively to feedback, focus on risks when facing new ideas or avoid certain situations which creates an impression that youâre difficult. Although these tendencies are often hard-wired into our brains we can do something about them. First, consider whether your ideas about colleagues are based on evidence. Figure out how you like to receive criticism and even when it doesnât come that way, master a few set responses that offer you more time to process the information. When you would like to avoid something, be honest with your team about why. And, when you react to new ideas, make sure to emphasize the positives as well as the negatives.															         Bill Cahill/Getty Images    I have an anxiety-prone brain. When presented with a new idea, my first instinct is usually to think of what could go wrong and the worst-case scenario. Whenever communication is ambiguous, the first conclusion I jump to is a negative one.If you share these tendencies, you wonât necessarily be able to change them, and nor do you need to; theyâre probably your hard-wired defaults, and they can yield positive outcomes, such as diligence and sensitivity to others. However, you can learn to recognize when youâre seeing through anxiety-tinted glasses and adjust your thinking so it doesnât limit you. Here are some common ways anxiety can cause problems at work and suggestions for ways to minimize them.You misjudge the view others have of you.Anxious folks tend to worry that others dislike them or donât see them as talented. For instance, letâs say a coworker doesnât greet you as warmly as they do others and always seems rushed in your interactions. You assume the person doesnât like you. But realistically, there are other possibilities: perhaps theyâre warmer with people they know better or their only way of socializing is to joke around and you give off a serious vibe. Because you donât feel liked, you avoid that colleague, but then they might feel snubbed and jump to the conclusion you donât like them!Instead, itâs important to recognize when youâre interpreting an interpersonal situation without solid evidence. Equally, if not more important, is to understand that even if your colleague isnât into you (professionally-speaking) you can still have a fruitful relationship.Youâre defensive about feedback.Anxious people are often driven to succeed, so they want feedback that helps them improve, but they tend to catastrophize it and see it as an indicator theyâre doomed to fail. If this sounds like you, get clear about what makes it easier for you to be open to criticism. For me, this includes getting it from someone whose advice I trust and who believes in my general competency/talent, having it sandwiched between positive comments, and receiving it via email (so I can digest it slowly) and when I ask for or expect it (to feel more in control).The flipside of knowing how you like to get feedback is recognizing how you donât and figuring out a way to get more comfortable in those scenarios. For instance, I find it hard to take critiques from new people but I also find fresh perspectives very valuable, so Iâm willing to tolerate the anxiety of it. Itâs also useful to have some canned responses for when feedback has caused your anxiety to spike and you need time to modulate your reaction â for instance: âThose are good points. Let me go away and think them through and come up with a game plan for how to implement your suggestions.âYou avoid situations then get perceived as difficult.We tend to avoid the things weâre anxious about and then feel ashamed about the avoidance, which causes us to be unclear in our communication. This problem can manifest itself in big and small ways. Maybe you feel awkward about responding to an email so procrastinate on it, which leaves the impression that youâre unreliable, disorganized, or confusing. Or maybe your clinical-level fear of flying is making you turn down work trips.In many cases itâs best to be honest about whatâs causing your hesitation. You wonât always receive the understanding you hope for but transparency reduces everyoneâs stress, enhances trust, and is often perceived as brave and authentic.You react negatively when presented with unexpected ideas.If your first thought when presented with new ideas is to consider the risks, downsides, and reasons they wonât work, other people are probably picking up on your instinct and, worse, may perceive it as unwelcome negativity. Even if itâs only your initial reaction, it can be demoralizing and annoying for others who do see a way to move forward.If youâre one of these naysayers, I recommend training yourself to give sandwich feedback. Make sure that your first response to a new idea is to note whatâs good about it. Doing this will help your brain improve at balanced thinking and benefit you overall. You can then mention your worries, but end on a positive note. Another strategy is to delay reacting, even by only a few hours, so that when you do respond, youâre giving a considered response.Anxiety can motivate people in very positive ways: for example, fear of rejection can make you work harder at and deeply value relationships, and being sensitive, cautious, and careful can enhance your performance on difficult tasks. The better you understand how your anxiety works, the more you can maximize these positive aspects and minimize the negative so youâre more accepting of yourself and better able to handle challenges that arise at work.																																																	Alice Boyes, PhD is a former clinical psychologist turned writer and is author of The Healthy Mind Toolkit and The Anxiety Toolkit. html.textContent: What to read next						                      						Where Measuring Engagement Goes Wrong																			Managing yourself											What Anxiety Does to Us at Work																					Alice Boyes																								May 17, 2019																																																							 Summary Full Text									 Save									 Share									 Comment									 Text Size									 Print																																																																								Recommended																				Harvard Business Review Guides...									Book																	300.00																				Add to Cart																																																									HBR Guide to Your Professional Growth									Book																	19.95																				Add to Cart																																																									HBR Emotional Intelligence Boxed Set...									Book																	99.99																				Add to Cart																																																				Executive Summary						Anxiety can cause you problems at work. Perhaps it leads you to misjudge what other people think of you, react defensively to feedback, focus on risks when facing new ideas or avoid certain situations which creates an impression that youâre difficult. Although these tendencies are often hard-wired into our brains we can do something about them. First, consider whether your ideas about colleagues are based on evidence. Figure out how you like to receive criticism and even when it doesnât come that way, master a few set responses that offer you more time to process the information. When you would like to avoid something, be honest with your team about why. And, when you react to new ideas, make sure to emphasize the positives as well as the negatives.															         Bill Cahill/Getty Images    I have an anxiety-prone brain. When presented with a new idea, my first instinct is usually to think of what could go wrong and the worst-case scenario. Whenever communication is ambiguous, the first conclusion I jump to is a negative one.If you share these tendencies, you wonât necessarily be able to change them, and nor do you need to; theyâre probably your hard-wired defaults, and they can yield positive outcomes, such as diligence and sensitivity to others. However, you can learn to recognize when youâre seeing through anxiety-tinted glasses and adjust your thinking so it doesnât limit you. Here are some common ways anxiety can cause problems at work and suggestions for ways to minimize them.You misjudge the view others have of you.Anxious folks tend to worry that others dislike them or donât see them as talented. For instance, letâs say a coworker doesnât greet you as warmly as they do others and always seems rushed in your interactions. You assume the person doesnât like you. But realistically, there are other possibilities: perhaps theyâre warmer with people they know better or their only way of socializing is to joke around and you give off a serious vibe. Because you donât feel liked, you avoid that colleague, but then they might feel snubbed and jump to the conclusion you donât like them!Instead, itâs important to recognize when youâre interpreting an interpersonal situation without solid evidence. Equally, if not more important, is to understand that even if your colleague isnât into you (professionally-speaking) you can still have a fruitful relationship.Youâre defensive about feedback.Anxious people are often driven to succeed, so they want feedback that helps them improve, but they tend to catastrophize it and see it as an indicator theyâre doomed to fail. If this sounds like you, get clear about what makes it easier for you to be open to criticism. For me, this includes getting it from someone whose advice I trust and who believes in my general competency/talent, having it sandwiched between positive comments, and receiving it via email (so I can digest it slowly) and when I ask for or expect it (to feel more in control).The flipside of knowing how you like to get feedback is recognizing how you donât and figuring out a way to get more comfortable in those scenarios. For instance, I find it hard to take critiques from new people but I also find fresh perspectives very valuable, so Iâm willing to tolerate the anxiety of it. Itâs also useful to have some canned responses for when feedback has caused your anxiety to spike and you need time to modulate your reaction â for instance: âThose are good points. Let me go away and think them through and come up with a game plan for how to implement your suggestions.âYou avoid situations then get perceived as difficult.We tend to avoid the things weâre anxious about and then feel ashamed about the avoidance, which causes us to be unclear in our communication. This problem can manifest itself in big and small ways. Maybe you feel awkward about responding to an email so procrastinate on it, which leaves the impression that youâre unreliable, disorganized, or confusing. Or maybe your clinical-level fear of flying is making you turn down work trips.In many cases itâs best to be honest about whatâs causing your hesitation. You wonât always receive the understanding you hope for but transparency reduces everyoneâs stress, enhances trust, and is often perceived as brave and authentic.You react negatively when presented with unexpected ideas.If your first thought when presented with new ideas is to consider the risks, downsides, and reasons they wonât work, other people are probably picking up on your instinct and, worse, may perceive it as unwelcome negativity. Even if itâs only your initial reaction, it can be demoralizing and annoying for others who do see a way to move forward.If youâre one of these naysayers, I recommend training yourself to give sandwich feedback. Make sure that your first response to a new idea is to note whatâs good about it. Doing this will help your brain improve at balanced thinking and benefit you overall. You can then mention your worries, but end on a positive note. Another strategy is to delay reacting, even by only a few hours, so that when you do respond, youâre giving a considered response.Anxiety can motivate people in very positive ways: for example, fear of rejection can make you work harder at and deeply value relationships, and being sensitive, cautious, and careful can enhance your performance on difficult tasks. The better you understand how your anxiety works, the more you can maximize these positive aspects and minimize the negative so youâre more accepting of yourself and better able to handle challenges that arise at work.																																																	Alice Boyes, PhD is a former clinical psychologist turned writer and is author of The Healthy Mind Toolkit and The Anxiety Toolkit. Book																	300.00																				Add to Cart																																																									HBR Guide to Your Professional Growth									Book																	19.95																				Add to Cart																																																									HBR Emotional Intelligence Boxed Set...									Book																	99.99																				Add to Cart																																																				Executive Summary						Anxiety can cause you problems at work. Perhaps it leads you to misjudge what other people think of you, react defensively to feedback, focus on risks when facing new ideas or avoid certain situations which creates an impression that youâre difficult. Although these tendencies are often hard-wired into our brains we can do something about them. First, consider whether your ideas about colleagues are based on evidence. Figure out how you like to receive criticism and even when it doesnât come that way, master a few set responses that offer you more time to process the information. When you would like to avoid something, be honest with your team about why. And, when you react to new ideas, make sure to emphasize the positives as well as the negatives.															         Bill Cahill/Getty Images    I have an anxiety-prone brain. When presented with a new idea, my first instinct is usually to think of what could go wrong and the worst-case scenario. Whenever communication is ambiguous, the first conclusion I jump to is a negative one.If you share these tendencies, you wonât necessarily be able to change them, and nor do you need to; theyâre probably your hard-wired defaults, and they can yield positive outcomes, such as diligence and sensitivity to others. However, you can learn to recognize when youâre seeing through anxiety-tinted glasses and adjust your thinking so it doesnât limit you. Here are some common ways anxiety can cause problems at work and suggestions for ways to minimize them.You misjudge the view others have of you.Anxious folks tend to worry that others dislike them or donât see them as talented. For instance, letâs say a coworker doesnât greet you as warmly as they do others and always seems rushed in your interactions. You assume the person doesnât like you. But realistically, there are other possibilities: perhaps theyâre warmer with people they know better or their only way of socializing is to joke around and you give off a serious vibe. Because you donât feel liked, you avoid that colleague, but then they might feel snubbed and jump to the conclusion you donât like them!Instead, itâs important to recognize when youâre interpreting an interpersonal situation without solid evidence. Equally, if not more important, is to understand that even if your colleague isnât into you (professionally-speaking) you can still have a fruitful relationship.Youâre defensive about feedback.Anxious people are often driven to succeed, so they want feedback that helps them improve, but they tend to catastrophize it and see it as an indicator theyâre doomed to fail. If this sounds like you, get clear about what makes it easier for you to be open to criticism. For me, this includes getting it from someone whose advice I trust and who believes in my general competency/talent, having it sandwiched between positive comments, and receiving it via email (so I can digest it slowly) and when I ask for or expect it (to feel more in control).The flipside of knowing how you like to get feedback is recognizing how you donât and figuring out a way to get more comfortable in those scenarios. For instance, I find it hard to take critiques from new people but I also find fresh perspectives very valuable, so Iâm willing to tolerate the anxiety of it. Itâs also useful to have some canned responses for when feedback has caused your anxiety to spike and you need time to modulate your reaction â for instance: âThose are good points. Let me go away and think them through and come up with a game plan for how to implement your suggestions.âYou avoid situations then get perceived as difficult.We tend to avoid the things weâre anxious about and then feel ashamed about the avoidance, which causes us to be unclear in our communication. This problem can manifest itself in big and small ways. Maybe you feel awkward about responding to an email so procrastinate on it, which leaves the impression that youâre unreliable, disorganized, or confusing. Or maybe your clinical-level fear of flying is making you turn down work trips.In many cases itâs best to be honest about whatâs causing your hesitation. You wonât always receive the understanding you hope for but transparency reduces everyoneâs stress, enhances trust, and is often perceived as brave and authentic.You react negatively when presented with unexpected ideas.If your first thought when presented with new ideas is to consider the risks, downsides, and reasons they wonât work, other people are probably picking up on your instinct and, worse, may perceive it as unwelcome negativity. Even if itâs only your initial reaction, it can be demoralizing and annoying for others who do see a way to move forward.If youâre one of these naysayers, I recommend training yourself to give sandwich feedback. Make sure that your first response to a new idea is to note whatâs good about it. Doing this will help your brain improve at balanced thinking and benefit you overall. You can then mention your worries, but end on a positive note. Another strategy is to delay reacting, even by only a few hours, so that when you do respond, youâre giving a considered response.Anxiety can motivate people in very positive ways: for example, fear of rejection can make you work harder at and deeply value relationships, and being sensitive, cautious, and careful can enhance your performance on difficult tasks. The better you understand how your anxiety works, the more you can maximize these positive aspects and minimize the negative so youâre more accepting of yourself and better able to handle challenges that arise at work.																																																	Alice Boyes, PhD is a former clinical psychologist turned writer and is author of The Healthy Mind Toolkit and The Anxiety Toolkit. html.textContent: Executive Summary						Anxiety can cause you problems at work. Perhaps it leads you to misjudge what other people think of you, react defensively to feedback, focus on risks when facing new ideas or avoid certain situations which creates an impression that youâre difficult. Although these tendencies are often hard-wired into our brains we can do something about them. First, consider whether your ideas about colleagues are based on evidence. Figure out how you like to receive criticism and even when it doesnât come that way, master a few set responses that offer you more time to process the information. When you would like to avoid something, be honest with your team about why. And, when you react to new ideas, make sure to emphasize the positives as well as the negatives.
html.nouns: Executive Summary						Anxiety problems misjudge people feedback, ideas situations impression youâre tendencies brains something ideas colleagues evidence.  criticism few responses more time information.  something, be team ideas, positives negatives.

html.textContent: Anxiety can cause you problems at work. Perhaps it leads you to misjudge what other people think of you, react defensively to feedback, focus on risks when facing new ideas or avoid certain situations which creates an impression that youâre difficult. Although these tendencies are often hard-wired into our brains we can do something about them. First, consider whether your ideas about colleagues are based on evidence. Figure out how you like to receive criticism and even when it doesnât come that way, master a few set responses that offer you more time to process the information. When you would like to avoid something, be honest with your team about why. And, when you react to new ideas, make sure to emphasize the positives as well as the negatives.
html.nouns: Anxiety problems misjudge people feedback, ideas situations impression youâre tendencies brains something ideas colleagues evidence.  criticism few responses more time information.  something, be team ideas, positives negatives.

html.textContent: Bill Cahill/Getty Images    I have an anxiety-prone brain. When presented with a new idea, my first instinct is usually to think of what could go wrong and the worst-case scenario. Whenever communication is ambiguous, the first conclusion I jump to is a negative one.If you share these tendencies, you wonât necessarily be able to change them, and nor do you need to; theyâre probably your hard-wired defaults, and they can yield positive outcomes, such as diligence and sensitivity to others. However, you can learn to recognize when youâre seeing through anxiety-tinted glasses and adjust your thinking so it doesnât limit you. Here are some common ways anxiety can cause problems at work and suggestions for ways to minimize them.You misjudge the view others have of you.Anxious folks tend to worry that others dislike them or donât see them as talented. For instance, letâs say a coworker doesnât greet you as warmly as they do others and always seems rushed in your interactions. You assume the person doesnât like you. But realistically, there are other possibilities: perhaps theyâre warmer with people they know better or their only way of socializing is to joke around and you give off a serious vibe. Because you donât feel liked, you avoid that colleague, but then they might feel snubbed and jump to the conclusion you donât like them!Instead, itâs important to recognize when youâre interpreting an interpersonal situation without solid evidence. Equally, if not more important, is to understand that even if your colleague isnât into you (professionally-speaking) you can still have a fruitful relationship.Youâre defensive about feedback.Anxious people are often driven to succeed, so they want feedback that helps them improve, but they tend to catastrophize it and see it as an indicator theyâre doomed to fail. If this sounds like you, get clear about what makes it easier for you to be open to criticism. For me, this includes getting it from someone whose advice I trust and who believes in my general competency/talent, having it sandwiched between positive comments, and receiving it via email (so I can digest it slowly) and when I ask for or expect it (to feel more in control).The flipside of knowing how you like to get feedback is recognizing how you donât and figuring out a way to get more comfortable in those scenarios. For instance, I find it hard to take critiques from new people but I also find fresh perspectives very valuable, so Iâm willing to tolerate the anxiety of it. Itâs also useful to have some canned responses for when feedback has caused your anxiety to spike and you need time to modulate your reaction â for instance: âThose are good points. Let me go away and think them through and come up with a game plan for how to implement your suggestions.âYou avoid situations then get perceived as difficult.We tend to avoid the things weâre anxious about and then feel ashamed about the avoidance, which causes us to be unclear in our communication. This problem can manifest itself in big and small ways. Maybe you feel awkward about responding to an email so procrastinate on it, which leaves the impression that youâre unreliable, disorganized, or confusing. Or maybe your clinical-level fear of flying is making you turn down work trips.In many cases itâs best to be honest about whatâs causing your hesitation. You wonât always receive the understanding you hope for but transparency reduces everyoneâs stress, enhances trust, and is often perceived as brave and authentic.You react negatively when presented with unexpected ideas.If your first thought when presented with new ideas is to consider the risks, downsides, and reasons they wonât work, other people are probably picking up on your instinct and, worse, may perceive it as unwelcome negativity. Even if itâs only your initial reaction, it can be demoralizing and annoying for others who do see a way to move forward.If youâre one of these naysayers, I recommend training yourself to give sandwich feedback. Make sure that your first response to a new idea is to note whatâs good about it. Doing this will help your brain improve at balanced thinking and benefit you overall. You can then mention your worries, but end on a positive note. Another strategy is to delay reacting, even by only a few hours, so that when you do respond, youâre giving a considered response.Anxiety can motivate people in very positive ways: for example, fear of rejection can make you work harder at and deeply value relationships, and being sensitive, cautious, and careful can enhance your performance on difficult tasks. The better you understand how your anxiety works, the more you can maximize these positive aspects and minimize the negative so youâre more accepting of yourself and better able to handle challenges that arise at work.
